citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
*One female Nubian goat, tan with white on her face, and housed at the petting farm area was noted to be thin on
inspection. Her ribs are visible and the processes of her backbone are prominent and sharp. Her hip bones are prominent
with little fat. The veterinarian has not been consulted regarding the thin body condition. Her last veterinary physical exam
was April 26, 2023 at which time the veterinarian gave her a normal weight body condition score.
*One prairie dog was seen during the inspection. The curator stated that they have five prairie dogs but they have not
seen more than two prairie dogs together at one time even with the use of a trail camera. Daily keeper records for the last
two months state that only one prairie dog was visualized by staff daily but that food fed for five was being provided and
eaten. It is unknown whether the prairie dog identified is always the same one or not. Veterinary visits noted for the group
for the last three years state that the veterinarian was not able to do a visual exam.
Daily observation of all animals is necessary to be able to assess their health and well-being and to notify the veterinarian
in a timely manner of any problems related to health, behavior or well-being of the animals so that they can be
appropriately addressed.
The facility shall ensure that daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being is being conducted and
that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication exists so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the goat be examined
by a veterinarian by 8/23/23 and developing a method to perform daily observation of the prairie dogs by 9/1/23.

Several outdoor housing areas were found to need repair.
*The enclosure housing six African Crested Porcupines has two sections of chain link fencing type material with green
plastic slats woven through the chain link forming lean-to like shade structures from the ground to about four feet tall.
Several of the green plastic slats are broken off. Some have sharp points. Others have chew marks on them. The
porcupines may injure themselves or ingest some of the plastic material.
*The hammocks for both the red fox and the raccoon are worn with a hole present in each and lots of fabric strings
dangling from the edges of the hole. The animals may injure themselves or ingest some of the fabric strings.
*The new and not yet being used goat climbing structure has an elevated (6 plus feet off the ground) steep ramp leading
to a protected platform. The ramp has no sides or other protective railing. The goats may injure themselves if they fall.
The outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury. Correct by 8/23/23.

The facility currently has an eight foot perimeter fence as required but the fence is in need of attention/maintenance. In
multiple sections, especially along the back side of the zoo, the perimeter fence has been overgrown by vines, bushes
and trees. Animals and unauthorized persons may use the growth to climb over the fence and have contact with the
animals in the facility. In addition, the growth makes it difficult to see the actual fence in some areas to evaluate the
condition of the fence and it may damage the actual fence itself.
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Correct by 10/16/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the curator and a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS
Lemnique Wafer, Assistant Director n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
*One female Nubian goat, tan with white on her face, and housed at the petting farm area was noted to be thin on 
inspection. Her ribs are visible and the processes of her backbone are prominent and sharp. Her hip bones are prominent 
with little fat. The veterinarian has not been consulted regarding the thin body condition. Her last veterinary physical exam 
was April 26, 2023 at which time the veterinarian gave her a normal weight body condition score.  
*One prairie dog was seen during the inspection. The curator stated that they have five prairie dogs but they have not 
seen more than two prairie dogs together at one time even with the use of a trail camera. Daily keeper records for the last 
two months state that only one prairie dog was visualized by staff daily but that food fed for five was being provided and 
eaten. It is unknown whether the prairie dog identified is always the same one or not. Veterinary visits noted for the group 
for the last three years state that the veterinarian was not able to do a visual exam.  
Daily observation of all animals is necessary to be able to assess their health and well-being and to notify the veterinarian 
in a timely manner of any problems related to health, behavior or well-being of the animals so that they can be 
appropriately addressed.  
The facility shall ensure that daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being is being conducted and 
that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication exists so that timely and accurate information on problems of 
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the goat be examined 
by a veterinarian by 8/23/23 and developing a method to perform daily observation of the prairie dogs by 9/1/23. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several outdoor housing areas were found to need repair. 
*The enclosure housing six African Crested Porcupines has two sections of chain link fencing type material with green 
plastic slats woven through the chain link forming lean-to like shade structures from the ground to about four feet tall. 
Several of the green plastic slats are broken off. Some have sharp points. Others have chew marks on them. The 
porcupines may injure themselves or ingest some of the plastic material.  
*The hammocks for both the red fox and the raccoon are worn with a hole present in each and lots of fabric strings 
dangling from the edges of the hole. The animals may injure themselves or ingest some of the fabric strings.  
*The new and not yet being used goat climbing structure has an elevated (6 plus feet off the ground) steep ramp leading 
to a protected platform. The ramp has no sides or other protective railing. The goats may injure themselves if they fall.

The outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury. Correct by 8/23/23. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility currently has an eight foot perimeter fence as required but the fence is in need of attention/maintenance. In 
multiple sections, especially along the back side of the zoo, the perimeter fence has been overgrown by vines, bushes 
and trees. Animals and unauthorized persons may use the growth to climb over the fence and have contact with the 
animals in the facility. In addition, the growth makes it difficult to see the actual fence in some areas to evaluate the 
condition of the fence and it may damage the actual fence itself.  
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can 
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Correct by 10/16/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the curator and a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS 
Lemnique Wafer, Assistant Director n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
